text: During the reign of which Persian king did Haggai prophesy?
verseText: In the second year of Darius the king, in the sixth month, on the first day of the month, the word of the LORD came by the hand of Haggai the prophet to Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and to Joshua the son of Jehozadak, the high priest.

text: What main task did Haggai urge the returned exiles to undertake?
verseText: “Is it a time for you yourselves to dwell in your paneled houses, while this house lies in ruins?... Go up to the hills and bring wood and build the house, that I may take pleasure in it and that I may be glorified, says the LORD.

text: According to Haggai 1, why were the people experiencing poor harvests and economic hardship?
options: Because they were neglecting God's house (the Temple)
verseText: You have sown much, and harvested little. You eat, but you never have enough; you drink, but you never have your fill. You clothe yourselves, but no one is warm. And he who earns wages does so to put them into a bag with holes. You looked for much, and behold, it came to little. And when you brought it home, I blew it away. Why? declares the LORD of hosts. Because of my house that lies in ruins, while each of you busies himself with his own house. Therefore the heavens above you have withheld the dew, and the earth has withheld its produce. And I have called for a drought on the land and the hills, on the grain, the new wine, the oil, on what the ground brings forth, on man and beast, and on all their labors.

text: Who were the two main leaders Haggai addressed?
verseText: ...the word of the LORD came by the hand of Haggai the prophet to Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and to Joshua the son of Jehozadak, the high priest.

text: How did the leaders and people respond to Haggai's first message?
options: They obeyed and began working on the Temple
verseText: Then Zerubbabel... and Joshua... with all the remnant of the people, obeyed the voice of the LORD their God... And the LORD stirred up the spirit of Zerubbabel... and the spirit of Joshua... and the spirit of all the remnant of the people. And they came and worked on the house of the LORD of hosts, their God,

text: What concern did some older people have about the second Temple (Haggai 2:3)?
options: It seemed insignificant compared to Solomon's Temple
It was in the wrong location
verseText: ‘Who is left among you who saw this house in its former glory? How do you see it now? Is it not as nothing in your eyes?’

text: What future promise did God give regarding the second Temple in Haggai 2:7-9?
options: It would be destroyed by enemies
He would fill it with glory, and the latter glory would be greater than the former
It would be replaced by a heavenly temple
It would be expanded by Herod
verseText: And I will shake all nations, so that the treasures of all nations shall come in, and I will fill this house with glory, says the LORD of hosts. The latter glory of this house shall be greater than the former, says the LORD of hosts. And in this place I will give peace, declares the LORD of hosts.

text: What principle did Haggai teach using the priests' rulings on holiness and defilement (Haggai 2:11-14)?
options: Defilement is contagious, and the people's neglect of the Temple had defiled their efforts
Only priests can handle holy things
verseText: ‘If someone carries holy meat in the fold of his garment... does it make it holy?’ The priests answered and said, ‘No.’... ‘If someone who is unclean by contact with a dead body touches any of these, does it become unclean?’ The priests answered and said, ‘It does become unclean.’ Then Haggai answered and said, ‘So is it with this people... and with all the work of their hands. And what they offer there is unclean.’

text: What specific promise did God make to Zerubbabel at the end of the book (Haggai 2:23)?
options: He would live a long life
He would be made like a signet ring, chosen by God
verseText: On that day, declares the LORD of hosts, I will take you, O Zerubbabel my servant, the son of Shealtiel, declares the LORD, and make you like a signet ring, for I have chosen you, declares the LORD of hosts.”

text: What is the central theme connecting all of Haggai's messages?
options: Prioritizing God's house and work leads to blessing
The coming judgment on the nations
verseText: (The contrast between neglect leading to curse and obedience leading to blessing is central throughout the book).

text: On what specific day did Haggai deliver his first message?
options: First day of the first month
First day of the sixth month, second year of Darius
Tenth day of the seventh month
verseText: In the second year of Darius the king, in the sixth month, on the first day of the month, the word of the LORD came by the hand of Haggai...

text: What phrase does Haggai repeatedly use to urge the people to reflect on their situation?
verseText: Now, therefore, thus says the LORD of hosts: Consider your ways!... Thus says the LORD of hosts: Consider your ways.

text: What specific problem did the people have with their houses compared to God's house (Haggai 1:4)?
options: They lived in paneled houses while God's house was in ruins
Their houses were built with stolen materials
verseText: “Is it a time for you yourselves to dwell in your paneled houses, while this house lies in ruins?

text: Haggai 1:6 describes the futility of the people's efforts before rebuilding the temple. Which is NOT mentioned?
options: Building houses, but having them collapse
Earning wages, only to put them in a purse with holes
verseText: You have sown much, and harvested little. You eat, but you never have enough; you drink, but you never have your fill. You clothe yourselves, but no one is warm. And he who earns wages does so to put them into a bag with holes.

text: Where did God tell the people to get wood for the Temple (Haggai 1:8)?
options: Use wood from their own houses
verseText: Go up to the hills and bring wood and build the house, that I may take pleasure in it and that I may be glorified, says the LORD.

text: What specific natural phenomenon did God say He called for due to their neglect (Haggai 1:11)?
options: A drought on the land, mountains, grain, wine, oil, etc.
verseText: Therefore the heavens above you have withheld the dew, and the earth has withheld its produce. And I have called for a drought on the land and the hills, on the grain, the new wine, the oil, on what the ground brings forth, on man and beast, and on all their labors.”

text: What role did the Holy Spirit play in the people's response (Haggai 1:14)?
options: The Spirit convicted them of sin
The LORD stirred up the spirit of the leaders and people
The Spirit gave them building plans
verseText: And the LORD stirred up the spirit of Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and the spirit of Joshua the son of Jehozadak, the high priest, and the spirit of all the remnant of the people. And they came and worked on the house of the LORD of hosts, their God,

text: On what day did the people actually begin working on the Temple after Haggai's first message?
options: The first day of the sixth month
The tenth day of the sixth month
The twenty-fourth day of the sixth month
The first day of the seventh month
verseText: And they came and worked on the house of the LORD of hosts, their God, on the twenty-fourth day of the month, in the sixth month, in the second year of Darius the king.

text: What encouraging message did God give through Haggai shortly after the work began (Haggai 1:13)?
verseText: Then Haggai, the messenger of the LORD, spoke to the people with the LORD's message, “I am with you, declares the LORD.”

text: When did Haggai deliver his second message, encouraging the builders (Haggai 2:1)?
options: The first day of the sixth month
The twenty-fourth day of the sixth month
The twenty-first day of the seventh month
The first day of the ninth month
verseText: In the seventh month, on the twenty-first day of the month, the word of the LORD came by the hand of Haggai the prophet,

text: What did God promise to 'shake' in Haggai 2:6-7?
options: The heavens and the earth, the sea and the dry land, and all nations
verseText: For thus says the LORD of hosts: Yet once more, in a little while, I am going to shake the heavens and the earth and the sea and the dry land. And I will shake all nations...

text: What belongs to the LORD, ensuring He can fill the Temple with glory (Haggai 2:8)?
verseText: The silver is mine, and the gold is mine, declares the LORD of hosts.

text: Besides greater glory, what else did God promise to give 'in this place' (the Temple) according to Haggai 2:9?
verseText: The latter glory of this house shall be greater than the former, says the LORD of hosts. And in this place I will give peace, declares the LORD of hosts.’”

text: When did Haggai deliver his third message concerning defilement and blessing (Haggai 2:10)?
verseText: On the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month, in the second year of Darius, the word of the LORD came by Haggai the prophet,

text: The priests confirmed that touching something holy does NOT automatically make something else holy, but touching something unclean DOES make something else unclean. What point was Haggai making about the people's past offerings (Haggai 2:14)?
options: Their offerings were acceptable despite their sin
Their neglect of the Temple (uncleanness) made all their other work and offerings unclean
Holiness could be transferred through offerings
verseText: Then Haggai answered and said, ‘So is it with this people, and with this nation before me, declares the LORD, and so with every work of their hands. And what they offer there is unclean.’

text: Haggai asks the people to 'consider' the time BEFORE the Temple foundation was laid again (Haggai 2:15-17). What characterized that time?
options: Poor yields (e.g., expecting 20 measures, getting 10) and crop diseases (blight, mildew, hail)
verseText: Before this time, when one came to a heap of twenty measures, there were but ten. When one came to the wine vat to draw fifty measures, there were but twenty. I struck you and all the products of your toil with blight and with mildew and with hail, yet you did not turn to me, declares the LORD.

text: What specific day does God tell them to 'consider' as the turning point, from which He would bless them (Haggai 2:18-19)?
options: The day they returned from exile
The twenty-fourth day of the ninth month, the day the Temple foundation was laid
The day the Temple was completed
verseText: Consider from this day onward, from the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month. Since the day that the foundation of the LORD's temple was laid, consider: Is the seed yet in the barn? Indeed, the vine, the fig tree, the pomegranate, and the olive tree have yielded nothing. But from this day on I will bless you.

text: What specific blessings are implied will begin 'from this day on' (Haggai 2:19)?
options: Agricultural abundance (vine, fig, pomegranate, olive yielding fruit)
verseText: Is the seed yet in the barn? Indeed, the vine, the fig tree, the pomegranate, and the olive tree have yielded nothing. But from this day on I will bless you.”

text: When did Haggai receive the final message specifically for Zerubbabel (Haggai 2:20)?
options: Same day as the first message
Same day as the second message
Same day as the third message (ninth month, twenty-fourth day)
verseText: The word of the LORD came a second time to Haggai on the twenty-fourth day of the month,

text: What did God say He would overthrow in the message to Zerubbabel (Haggai 2:21-22)?
options: The throne of kingdoms, the power of the kingdoms of the nations, chariots and riders
verseText: “Speak to Zerubbabel, governor of Judah, saying, I am about to shake the heavens and the earth, and to overthrow the throne of kingdoms. I am about to destroy the strength of the kingdoms of the nations, and overthrow the chariots and their riders. And the horses and their riders shall go down, every one by the sword of his brother.

text: What does a 'signet ring' typically represent, relating to the promise to Zerubbabel (Haggai 2:23)?
options: Authority, authenticity, and a close relationship (often royal)
verseText: ...and make you like a signet ring, for I have chosen you, declares the LORD of hosts.”

text: Zerubbabel was a descendant of which Israelite king, making the 'signet ring' promise significant?
verseText: (Zerubbabel's lineage traces back to David, linking this promise to the Davidic covenant).

text: Haggai's contemporary prophet, who also encouraged the Temple rebuilding, was:
verseText: Now the prophets, Haggai and Zechariah the son of Iddo, prophesied to the Jews who were in Judah and Jerusalem, in the name of the God of Israel who was over them.

text: How much time passed between Haggai's first message and the final message recorded in the book?
verseText: (First message: 6th month, 1st day. Last message: 9th month, 24th day. This is less than four months).

text: The issue of 'paneled houses' (Haggai 1:4) suggests the people had time and resources for what?
verseText: “Is it a time for you yourselves to dwell in your paneled houses, while this house lies in ruins?

text: God's promise to make the latter glory of the house greater than the former (Haggai 2:9) ultimately points towards:
options: The presence of Christ (Messiah) in the second Temple era
verseText: (The 'treasure/desire of all nations' and greater glory/peace are often interpreted messianically, fulfilled in Jesus' presence and work).

text: What was the primary reason God wanted the Temple rebuilt, according to Haggai 1:8?
options: That He might take pleasure in it and be glorified
To provide a place for sacrifices
verseText: Go up to the hills and bring wood and build the house, that I may take pleasure in it and that I may be glorified, says the LORD.

text: The structure of Haggai's book is largely built around:
options: A series of dated prophetic messages
verseText: (The book is clearly structured around four messages delivered on specific dates).

text: The book of Haggai demonstrates that obedience to God's priorities leads to:
verseText: “I am with you, declares the LORD.” ... “But from this day on I will bless you.”
